title: 106_s1468
content: The Act is titled the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". It includes findings related to the Act. Congress finds that in the year 1800, it first convened in the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., which is now a symbol of democracy with 5,000,000 annual visitors lacking proper facilities. The Capitol has excellent security provided by the United States Capitol Police, and $100,000,000 has been allocated for a Capitol Visitor Center to enhance security and visitor experience. Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for the construction of a Capitol Visitor Center, with the opportunity for private fundraising. Coins commemorating the first convening of Congress in the Capitol building will be sold to aid in the construction, maintenance, and preservation of the Visitor Center. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions as outlined in the Act. The Act specifies the minting of bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. Additionally, if bimetallic coins are not feasible, up to 100,000 $5 gold coins may be minted with different specifications. All coins minted under this Act are legal tender. The Secretary will obtain platinum and gold for minting coins from available sources, and may obtain silver from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins is specified in the Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building. Each coin will include the coin's value, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building. The design shall be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins under this Act will symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various committees. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each combination of denomination and quality. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish a role for promoting, advertising, and marketing the coins, and may enter into a contract with the Commission or a designated entity for this purpose. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Commission or an entity to promote the sale of coins minted under this Act. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge established by the Secretary. The surcharge amounts are $50 per coin for the $10 coin, $35 per coin for the $5 coin, $10 per coin for the $1 coin, and $3 per coin for the half dollar coin. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales deposited in Capitol Preservation Fund for construction, maintenance, and preservation of Capitol Visitor Center. Passed Senate on July 30, 1999.
